com.printscript.lpr
Class jLpr

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--com.printscript.lpr.jLpr
public class jLpr
extends java.lang.Object

jLpr provides an interface to LPD print servers running on network hosts and network connected printers.

It conforms to RFC 1179.

 boolean getPrintRaw()

          Print a file to a network host or printer
 void setPrintRaw(boolean printRawData)
          By default jLpr prints all files as raw binary data, if you need to use the text formatting of the spooler on your host set this value to false
 void setUseOutOfBoundPorts(boolean OutOfBoundsPorts)
          The RFC for lpr specifies the use of local ports numbered 721 - 731, however TCP/IP also requires that any port that is used will not be released for 3 minutes which means that jLpr will get stuck on the 12th job if prints are sent quickly.

Method Detail

setPrintRaw

public void setPrintRaw(boolean printRawData)
By default jLpr prints all files as raw binary data, if you need to use the text formatting of the spooler on your host set this value to false

getPrintRaw

public boolean getPrintRaw()
See Also:
setPrintRaw(boolean)

setUseOutOfBoundPorts

public void setUseOutOfBoundPorts(boolean OutOfBoundsPorts)
The RFC for lpr specifies the use of local ports numbered 721 - 731, however TCP/IP also requires that any port that is used will not be released for 3 minutes which means that jLpr will get stuck on the 12th job if prints are sent quickly. To resolve this issue you can use out of bounds ports which most print servers will support The default for this is off

getUseOutOfBoundPorts

public boolean getUseOutOfBoundPorts()
See Also:
setUseOutOfBoundPorts(boolean)

See Also:
printFile(String , String , String , String )

printFile

public void printFile(java.lang.String fileName,
                      java.lang.String hostName,
                      java.lang.String printerName,
                      java.lang.String documentName)
               throws java.io.IOException,
                      java.lang.InterruptedException
Print a file to a network host or printer
Parameters:
fileName - The path to the file to be printed
hostName - The host name or IP address of the print server
printerName - The name of the remote queue or the port on the print server
documentName - The name of the document as displayed in the spooler of the host
